name: Rhinoceros Viper
description: The rhinoceros viper differs from the nominate subspecies by the presence of horn-like protrusions on its nasal scales. Otherwise, it has a similarly robust body, a large angular head, and perfect camouflage coloring.
spread_note: West Africa, from Ghana to Guinea
image_alt: Rhinoceros viper, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Length 150–200 cm, with the tail about 10% of the length; weight 8 (up to 16) kg
attractions: The Gaboon viper is perfectly camouflaged in tropical forest environments with its coloration and body shape, lying in wait on the ground for prey. Its venomous fangs can reach up to 5 cm, and its venom is highly potent. Bites are rare, however, as this snake is relatively inactive. Its slow metabolism allows it to fast for up to 18 months.
breeding: Gaboon vipers were kept at the zoo in the 1960s. After a break, several individuals of the subspecies B. gabonica rhinoceros arrived in 1990, and we continue to keep them today.
